												I originally purchased this game around the time that the sequel - Euro Truck Simulator 2 - was getting rave reviews. So why not buy the sequel? Because it was priced ten times more and - reviews aside - it seemed doubtful I would enjoy a game where I tediously drove a truck down highways avoiding traffic hauling cargo. At least, I thought,  the first game would give me an idea if I could even stomach the genre. And if it did, well only then would I consider paying the price for the sequel.I was surprised out how engaging this game was. Perhaps because it stood in such stark contrast to all my other driving games (the Need For Speed series, Burnout Paradise, and similar), but there was something very relaxing  and enjoyable about driving between the lanes, making a point not to speed (much) and slam into other cars. It was almost zenlike. The graphics might not be particularly impressive but they got the point across, and the AI of the other cars was pleasantly non-aggressive. Figuring out the best routes to take and what cargos to deliver was not particularly challenging but it was relaxing, and a welcome change from the ordinary.Sadly, that's not enough to sustain the game, at least not for me. Having advanced three tiers and played over twenty hours, the lack of variety is increasingly noticeable. All the highways and cities more or less look the same and the challenge is flat throughout. So while it was a wonderful ride up to this point, it wasn't enough to keep me playing until the nominal "end" of the simulation. However, it /was/ enough to get me interested in the sequel, which apparently adds extra content and gameplay. And since that was the whole point of my playing this game in the first place, I consider it time and money well spent.

												As a person who has been a flight simulator addict for going on three decades now...  ( I cut my teeth on a green screen IBM bootleg copy of Pilot trainer circa 1988 )  I have often been skeptical of the 'ground runners.'  Trains, racing cars and boats all have the same singular fundementle flaw on the virtual stage.  Primarily that no matter how much you REALLY want it to be true, you are NOT going to get a realistic perspective view of ... well ... ANYTHING.  Land and city scapes will always be a generic  reflection of what you just saw and are about to see again.  SO; having established my rational for skepticesm, what am I doing here?  To put it plainly.  I'm cheap and my entertainment budget can be bought.  In short for $20 I got the whole euro-truken-paint joben collection.  You should too, hopefully here is why....Pro # 1.It's Europe and there isn't a freken war going on.  Well okay...  Actually about 2 thirds of Europe.  Sans the Balkans half of Italy and 1/3 of Iberia.  If you like Scandanavia.  You are officially S.O.L.  Rather Ironic in fact, considering that no less than half of the riggs you use in this series are models made in either Sweden or Norway.  Back to the point.  See something of the great old country without having to shoot it, dog fight over it or deal with Hitler or Napoleon.# 2. Beautifully simple.  Elegantly addictive.  I honestly went into this game with little if any knowledge of truck driving and after 6 hours that passed by like 30 minutes, I not only know something about the actual life style, I can also add that it was fun doing something curiously different than trying to beat a bunch of crazies to a finish line.The one and only con I can come up with, is that the technology of it's day DOES let it down somewhat.  However; as I mentioned before I got the collection so I expect the second edition to be a bit more advanced.  Not only graphic wise but the over all control experience.  This first one is the best to learn on.  If you can get comfy with this one then you can graduate to more complicated challenges.Jim

												I really enjoy this game, even though people may think it's boring to keep driving back and fourth to different cities to only drop off cargoes in order to gain more money. Although there is less cities to drive to, I still enjoy it. I love the feeling to be able to drive properly, and have played 20 hours within 2 days due to being obsessed. I'm not saying the game is perfect, hell, the second game might not even be perfect (can't buy it since I have a Mac) however it still is fun.I am quite big on graphics, and I have to admit this isn't so bad. The trucks/cars both look great and so does the interior of the trucks. You can either drive on manual or automatic which adds realism, and so does the various types of weather, time, and the rules of the road. Sound doesn't seem to be much of a problem, it has realistic car, weather, truck and engine noises.Having to deliver more and more in order to gain more money, does take a lot of time. But this leads to the game being more addictive and actually worth it. However, if driving back and forth for a while isn't really your thing, this can become a problem, though I ensure it wont be when you actually try it out, and even better, unlock more places.One thing that has annoyed me while driving around on here is how stupid the other drivers are. They either go the wrong way, beep at me when I am not doing anything wrong, and/or randomly brake when there was no need to which leads me into hitting them, which leads to me having to pay for hitting them. Adding pedestrians or animals would also be something which would make the game better (no I do not want to run them over)Another thing is how the cities are extremely small, and only have up to 5-6 roads, which is bad for when you want to explore other places other than the highway. The sound is good, but not so great. It sounds like I'm driving ontop of the truck rather than inside (might be because the windows are always open for some reason) and the radio does not sound like it's actually coming out of a radio in the truck.Honestly, I love this game even though it has some flaws which I have to live with, however those are probably fixed in ETS2. I recommend this game if you either have a older computer, have a Mac and cannot buy the second one (which is my case) or have a few cash left or is low on cash to spend it on this. An overall 6/10 from me.

From then on in, it concentrated on the American theater with its successful 18 Wheels of Steel series. 												Euro Truck Simulator is a 2008 truck simulation game created by SCS Software, using OpenGL, set in Europe. The player can drive across a depiction of Europe, visiting its cities, picking up a variety of cargos, and delivering them. Over 300,000 copies of the game have been sold in Europe. Its followup, Euro Truck Simulator 2, was released in 2012.Players choose their starting country, from Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, France, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Spain, Switzerland and the United Kingdom (V1.2 & V1.3 only). Initially players only have access to their starting country, except if it contains less than three cities. In this case one or more adjacent countries will be accessible as well. For example, starting the game in Italy or Switzerland, you get connection to the other for free. Then, players choose their first truck with a budget of €100,000.After this, players can start taking jobs from various fictitious companies and delivering cargo to various cities in their starting country to earn money. This money can then be spent on a new truck, upgrading the current truck, expanding the business to other countries and obtaining a license to drive flammables and chemicals.

												First off, if you want to play this game with the keyboard, you'll be disappointed. You need some kind of wheel for nice smooth turns, otherwilse curves will just be a bunch of corners. You have to make quite a few runs to advance your certification and to expand into other countires. I don't mind this since I prefer games a bit more on the relaxing side.While realizing that most drivers are idiots, my only wish is for a little more realism on the part of the AI traffic. A car or truck will stop short in front of you for no apparent reason. Don't tailgate and you'll be ok.I recommend this game if you are into simulation. I must emphasize again though. Am seriously considering getting the sequel Euro Truck Simulator 2 now as there are often times when I can't sleep and I know it would help.

												I'm really not sure how this got to be popular. The driving feels far too heavy to be enjoyable, even for a simulator, and there are so, so many bugs in the physics engine and the AI's control of their vehicles for me to avoid running out of money while transporting goods.The AI change lanes as fast as the cars on the freeways in GTA: San Andreas did - i.e. faster than your lumbering starter truck could ever hope to. This often causes pileups as although your brakes are terrible, the AI's brakes are worse.The character model is horribly dated, even for 2008 - while your truck is quite a pretty piece of graphics, the character driving it has a grand total of three different animations - "turn left, turn right, not turning", and they jar horribly if you're viewing the vehicle from the front.It appears to be very, very quickly churned out by a junior company for a driving school, not a full fledged trucking game which I hoped.I heard the sequel is better.

Posted: October 15, 2016
												As a casual player who doesn't really play casual games, I can only think of a single reason to play such a game: The Scenery. But this game has none.  Everthing seems the just same. Details are poorer than driving games 10 years older than that. Different places are hardly distinuishable, cities are really sparse (ie, in Switzerland there is only Bern, in Italy just Rome and Milan), and when you visit them, they just look like small villages in the middle of nowhere. Perhaps that's what a truck driver sees, visiting only the industrial areas of citiies, but, even so, not once I experienced the magnificence of observing a really large city from a distance.Music is inexistent; still no radio stations available after 4 hours of playtime, so I had to open an external music player to listen to while driving. Controls are not satisfying either (quite clumpsy), but perhaps I'm using the wrong truck.To give you an idea about "role playing" part, I have to repeatedly drive between Bern and Rome about 15 times, just to unlock a new area, in the hope of seeing something barely different.From the trading aspect, there are no real choices: Just sort the missions and take the one that gives the most money. Taking short missions is not a clever choice imho, due to the time lost during long manuevers inside "cities".Besides the relatively prototype idea, nothing interesting.

												SImple curiosity brought me to Euro Truck Simulator; I kinda felt like trying a more realistic/unusual simulator (my only experiences with simulators has been Kerbal and Sim Cities).What I got was pretty much what I expected.  Drive around, looking at environment as you try to do your best on deliveries; small goals with small challenges, that were momentarily rewarding.  The biggest problem I've found has been a lack of detailed roads and customization in your truck.  I'm not saying go crazy, but I never found any ways you could modify or trick out your truck at a small fee.  If they are there, it would have been nice to have the tutorial point you in that direction; this also kinda illustrates the problem with your truck/sleepiness/cargo status.  Didn't really make it clear what the ramifications are of not sleeping, following road rules, etc.Beyond that, its moderately interesting.  I feel like only a select few types of people would get enough enjoyment out of this to legitimize the full price, but at $2.50, might be worth a pick up if you're curious.

												I guess this is a fantastic simulation of driving a truck across Europe, at least in one regard: within the first hour or so, I felt the same degree of boredom that I can only assume truck drivers deal with on a daily basis. If you can tolerate repeating that task over and over until you've earned sufficient money, you get to buy a bigger, shinier rig so that you can -- drumroll please -- continue doing the same thing some more!Trust me, it is precisely as monotonous as it sounds.  DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine Euro Trcuk Simulator is a driving simulator game developed by SCS Software, the same people behind the 18 Wheels of Steel franchise and the Bus Driver game along with many other simulation gamesA bit of history as to how I knew SCS Software and why I love their games, I orignally discovered SCS Software's games with 18 Wheels of Steel, a trucking game which took place in countries all over the worldI loved the game so much that my family relatives would always get me an 18 Wheels of Steel game for Christmas or my birthday, all the way to the last game in the series titled: 18 Wheels of Steel: Extreme Trucker 2 which ended my love of the 18 Wheels of Steel seriesI also played the bus simulator game known as Bus Driver and both the 18 Wheels of Steel games and the Bus Driver, I now own all of them on retail, however you can now buy them digitally on SteamNow with the history lesson out of the way, let's go onto Euro Truck SimulatorEuro Truck Simulator takes place in the lovely continent known as Europe where you can drive and deliver items to all sorts of companies across Europe. From the United Kingdom to Germany and from Italy to France and so onThe game is extremely relaxing as you just drive on long highway roads travelling from one country to another. However, the game does also penalize you for driving incorrectly such as going the wrong way, through a red traffic light, driving on the wrong side of the road, hitting a car or a truck, no indicators, speeding and so on. So it's not all relax on the busy streets of EuropeYou deliver all sorts of items from food to livestock to hardware and big bulky things across the European landscapes and deliver it to your next port of call. The game is extremely easy yet oddly satisfying, relaxing and a huge time wasterThe game's graphics are okay but do show their age. Euro Truck Simulator came out in 2008 and uses an older engine that SCS Software uses on their games. I know because some of the graphical options, sound effects and even music is recycled from SCS Software's other games of the time such as the 18 Wheels of Steel series and the Bus Driver game which came out a year before in 2007This may put off some people but for me I don't really care for graphics, however, if you want prettier graphics than I highly recommend the sequel, Euro Truck Simulator 2 or it's American counterpart, American Trcuk Simulator which has prettier graphics and better A.I.When it comes to the recommendation of whether or not Euro Trcuk Simualtor is the game for you, if you like games that are simulation games and likes games where you just drive around and deliver stuff, then Euro Truck Simualtor is the game for you, otherwise, don't even botherIf you are going for graphical fidelity, I would highly recommend Euro Truck Simulator 2 or American Truck Simulator as they have prettier graphics, better A.I. and more content. If you want to have the SCS Software collection of games, then by all means, start with Euro Truck Simulator DRIVE SAFE!   RECOMMENDED :)

												Basically a good truck simulator game to check and out and get your feet wet if you can get it on sale.  I played this for a little while until Euro Truck Simulator 2 came out and was glad I bought this first at a really low price just to be sure that I would like it.  It introduced me to game mechanics which proved useful when I got into the second game, plus this game was easy to jump into and just have fun without being overly complicated.  After playing Euro Truck Simulator 2 for a while, I came back to this game and still liked it, although the steering controls are definitely "bouncy" and "floaty" compared to the second game which is much more refined.  As I say, this is a good game to check out if you are not sure if you would like this sort of thing or if you want something that is easy to get into, or just have a low-end system.  Recommended.  It does have Spain and Portugal which are not in the second game as of this writing in December 2016.
